topic.name: Colonial Foundations & North American Peoples
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Colonial Foundations & North American Peoples in History & Social Studies

objectives.objective_text: Identify the 13 stripes on the flag.
Name the three groups: North, Middle, and South.
Identify William Penn and Roger Williams.
Identify ships crossing the ocean.
Name Columbus and the Pilgrims.
Identify the Mayflower Compact.
Identify the first people who lived in America.
Name different homes like teepees, longhouses, and pueblos.
Identify the 'Three Sisters' (corn, beans, squash).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Identify Pocahontas and John Smith.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Name Squanto who helped the Pilgrims.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Identify the House of Burgesses (first voting group).
Identify George Whitefield as a man with a loud voice.
Name Jonathan Edwards.
Recall that Quakers lived in Pennsylvania.
Observe a map of the 13 colonies.
Recall that they wanted gold and freedom to pray.
Observe a map of the Atlantic Ocean.
Recall that they hunted, fished, and farmed.
Observe beautiful patterns in Native American art.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Recall the First Thanksgiving.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Observe that life was very hard in the new land.
Recall that many people started loving Jesus again.
Observe pictures of outdoor preaching.
Summarize the economy of each region (Farms vs. Ships).
Explain why the Middle Colonies were called the 'Breadbasket'.
Explain the role of indentured servitude.
Defend the thesis that regional differences laid the groundwork for the Civil War.
Summarize the three G's: God, Gold, and Glory.
Explain why the Pilgrims left England (religious freedom).
Explain the concept of a 'City on a Hill'.
Defend the complexity of the settlers (seeking liberty yet displacing others).
Summarize the differences between Plains, Woodland, and Southwest tribes.
Explain how geography shaped their way of life (buffalo vs. fish).
Explain the role of oral tradition in preserving history.
Defend the dignity of indigenous cultures while acknowledging tribal warfare.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the 'Starving Time' in Jamestown.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Explain how tobacco saved Virginia's economy.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Explain the causes and results of King Philip's War.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Defend the contributions of the Puritans to American education and law.
Summarize the impact of Whitefield's preaching tour.
Explain what a 'Revival' is.
Explain the itinerant preacher model.
Defend the necessity of personal conversion in American Christianity.
Compare the religious diversity of Pennsylvania with Massachusetts.
Analyze the impact of geography on the development of slavery in the South.
Interpret the triangular trade routes.
Connect the Quaker belief in equality to their treatment of Native Americans.
Compare the Spanish goals (conquest) with English goals (settlement).
Analyze the push/pull factors for migration.
Interpret the Virginia Company charter (economic motive).
Connect the Protestant Reformation to the settlement of New England.
Compare the Iroquois Confederacy with a tribe led by a chief.
Analyze the cultural and spiritual beliefs of major tribal groups.
Interpret the impact of European contact (trade and disease).
Connect the concept of land ownership (communal vs. private) to future conflict.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Compare the 'Separatists' (Plymouth) with the 'Puritans' (Mass. Bay).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the Mayflower Compact as a seed of self-government.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the social structure of the Puritan community.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Connect the geography of the Chesapeake to the rise of slavery.
Compare a 'New Light' (emotional) with an 'Old Light' (traditional).
Apply the idea that God can change a whole country.
Analyze Edwards' sermon 'Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God'.
Interpret the unifying effect of the Awakening on the colonies.
Connect the spiritual equality preached to the political idea of equality.
Evaluate the development of democratic institutions (Town Halls vs. County Courts).
Evaluate the theological motivations of the Puritans.
Evaluate the 'Pristine Myth' (that the land was untouched before Europeans).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the Salem Witch Trials in historical and spiritual context.
Evaluate the emotionalism vs. theological depth of the movement.
Construct a comparative analysis of the social hierarchies in the three regions.
Synthesize the concept of 'Salutary Neglect'.
Construct a comparison of French, Spanish, and British colonial models.
Synthesize the economic theory of Mercantilism driving colonization.
Construct a profile of pre-Columbian civilization complexity (Cahokia).
Synthesize the diversity of governance among Native nations.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Construct a profile of the 'New England Way' (church and state).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Jamestown, Plymouth, and the Great Migration
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the shift from religious zeal to commercial success.
Construct an argument linking the Great Awakening to the American Revolution.
Synthesize the breakdown of denominational barriers.
